headline: Potato-Parsnip Rosti with Caramelized Onion Sour Cream
description: If you’re looking for a starchy Hanukkah dish that’s *like* latkes but doesn’t require the patience of frying, flipping, and keeping them warm, say hello to the rosti.
recipeIngredient: 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, divided

recipeInstructions.name: Step 1: Make the dip (optional):
recipeInstructions.text: Peel, halve, and thinly slice 1 medium onion (about 2 cups). Finely chop fresh chives until you have 2 tablespoons.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 2: Make the dip (optional):
recipeInstructions.text: Melt 2 tablespoons unsalted butter In a medium skillet over medium-low heat. Add the onion and cook, stirring occasionally, until deep golden-brown and caramelized, 30 to 40 minutes. If you start to notice any charring, turn your heat down and add a splash of water.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 3: Make the dip (optional):
recipeInstructions.text: Remove from the heat and season with 1/4 teaspoon of the kosher salt and 1/4 teaspoon of the black pepper. Transfer to a cutting board, roughly chop them, then place them in a medium bowl. Set aside to cool to room temperature. Meanwhile, make the rosti.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 1: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Peel 1 pound russet potatoes, 1 medium parsnip, and 1/2 medium yellow onion. Cut all the vegetables into pieces that are thin enough to fit in the feed tube of a food processor, then shred with the shredding disk. (Alternatively, grate everything on the large holes of a box grater.)

recipeInstructions.name: Step 2: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Transfer the vegetable mixture onto a large triple layer of cheesecloth or clean kitchen towel. Wrap up the vegetables, then twist and squeeze the bundle over the sink until no more liquid comes out.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 3: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Melt 3 tablespoons of the unsalted butter in a large microwave-safe bowl (alternatively, melt on the stovetop and transfer to a large bowl). Add the vegetable mixture, 2 teaspoons kosher salt, and 1/2 teaspoon black pepper. Mix with a rubber spatula or your hands until combined.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 4: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Heat 1 tablespoon of the unsalted butter and 1 tablespoon olive oil over medium heat in an 8-inch nonstick frying pan or cast iron skillet until sizzling. Swirl the pan so the fat coats the bottom and goes up the sides. Add the potato mixture and evenly distribute in the pan, making sure to place some of the mixture up the sides of the skillet. Do not press the mixture into the skillet, you want to keep this as light and airy and possible.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 5: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Cook undisturbed until the bottom is golden-brown and crispy, 8 to 10 minutes. You can check the color by using a rubber spatula and gently nudging up a small piece of the rosti from the edge of the skillet.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 6: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Invert a plate that is wider than the skillet over the skillet. Grasping both the pan and the plate with hands protected in oven mitts, flip the rosti onto the plate.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 7: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Place the pan back over medium heat and add the remaining 1 tablespoon unsalted butter and remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil. Once the fat is sizzling, swirl the pan again. Slide the rosti back into the pan browned-side up. Cook undisturbed until the second side is golden-brown and crispy, about 8 minutes. Meanwhile, finish the dip.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 8: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Add the chives, 3/4 cup sour cream, juice of 1/2 medium lemon (about 1 1/2 tablespoons), remaining 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, and remaining 1/4 teaspoon black pepper to the caramelized onions. Stir to combine.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 9: Make the rosti:
recipeInstructions.text: Transfer the rosti to a plate or cutting board and cut into wedges. Serve with the sour cream dip.

HowtoTip.text: Make ahead: The onion for the dip can be caramelized up to 1 day ahead and refrigerated.Storage: Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

video.name: Potato Parsnip Rosti
video.description:
I will never say no to a latke. Never. But let’s face it: Frying latkes can be ... a process. I know, I know. It’s Hanukkah, and we’re celebrating the oil symbolic of the candles that burned for a miraculous eight days. No offense to Judah and his Maccabees, but sometimes I'm just not in the mood for splattering my whole stovetop with latke grease. The answer to this dilemma? A crispy potato rosti.

Check out the full recipe post [HERE](https://www.thekitchn.com/potato-parsnip-rosti-recipe-23106763)

name: Potato-Parsnip Rosti with Caramelized Onion Sour Cream

author.name: Sara Tane
author.description: Sara Tane is a food writer and private chef based in Los Angeles, CA (with her dog, Pepper). She is a graduate of the Institute of Culinary Education and has written for Food52, Good Housekeeping, Cooking Light, and AllRecipes. She also has a serious thing for oysters.
